did.unittitle: Herman Beerman and Thomas Hart collections of Sherlockiana

bioghist.p: Herman Beerman (1901-1995) was one of the founders of the Society for Investigative Dermatology, which established the Annual Herman Beerman Lecture in 1960. He was also a founder and early president of the American Society of Dermatopathology, and chaired the Department of Dermatology at the University of Pennsylvania from 1949 to 1967. Beerman was an eminent dermatologist and an enthusiastic Sherlockian, and he combined his two worlds by founding The Sir James Saunders Society for dermatologists who shared his enjoyment of the Canon. Sherlock Holmes is a famous fictional detective of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, who first appeared in publication in 1887. He is the creation of Scottish-born author and physician Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of Sherlockiana collected by Herman Beerman and Thomas Hart and given to the Athenaeum. The Beerman materials include: a framed thank you note signed by A. Conan Doyle; a color illustration of Sherlock Holmes; a silhouette of Holmes by Ben Wolf; Beerman's membership certificate to the Baker Street Irregulars; a bank check featuring an image of Sherlock Holmes; and a plaque awarded to Herman Beerman as Consultant to the Sir James Saunders Society, 1984. Other items collected by Beerman include: a meerschaum pipe; an audiocassette tape of Dvorak's 8th Symphony; an audiocassette tape of Sherlockian esoterica; swizzle sticks; ballpoint pens; a medal featuring the image of Arthur Conan Doyle; business cards of Sherlock Homes, Mycroft Holmes, and Professor Moriarty; a soap sculpture of Sherlock Holmes; a small pewter silhouette of Holmes; a ceramic plate depicting John Watson; a tin cannister; 35mm slides of Sherlockian meetings, movie stills, and illustrations of Holmes tales; and a Sherlock Holmes wooden nutcracker. The collection also includes a framed certificate belonging to Thomas Hart given to him by the Sons of the Copper Beeches, 1958.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
